  • Aggregators
  • View page source

Aggregators

The pyensemblefs.aggregators subpackage implements multiple families of aggregation methods that operate on bootstrap outputs (scores, ranks, or binary supports). These correspond to the score-based, rank-based, subset-based and approval-based (ABC) rules described in the paper.

Overview

All aggregators follow a common contract defined in pyensemblefs.aggregators.base.BaseAggregator:

  • Input is a 2D array results of shape (n_bootstraps, n_features).

  • aggregate() returns a 1D vector of length n_features (scores, ranks or a binary mask, depending on the subclass).

  • fit() computes an internal ranking and a selection mask based on top_k and the aggregated values.

Aggregator families

Score-based aggregators

Defined in pyensemblefs.aggregators.score, they treat higher values as better and work directly on real-valued matrices of scores (e.g., feature importances or relevance scores per bootstrap):

  • pyensemblefs.aggregators.score.MeanAggregator Arithmetic mean of scores across bootstraps.

  • pyensemblefs.aggregators.score.SumAggregator Sum of scores across bootstraps.

  • pyensemblefs.aggregators.score.MedianAggregator Median of scores (robust to outliers).

  • pyensemblefs.aggregators.score.TrimmedMeanAggregator Alpha-trimmed mean, removing a fraction of lowest and highest scores.

  • pyensemblefs.aggregators.score.WinsorizedMeanAggregator Winsorized mean, clipping extremes to alpha-quantiles.

  • pyensemblefs.aggregators.score.GeometricMeanAggregator Geometric mean, emphasizing consistently high scores.

  • pyensemblefs.aggregators.score.RankProductAggregator Rank-product style aggregation on scores (log-domain), returning -log-product so that higher values indicate more stable high scores.

  • pyensemblefs.aggregators.score.WeightedScoreAggregator Weighted average of scores across bootstraps, using user-provided weights.

  • pyensemblefs.aggregators.score.BordaFromScoresAggregator Converts per-bootstrap scores to ranks and applies Borda count, summing Borda points across bootstraps.

  • pyensemblefs.aggregators.score.SelectionFrequencyAggregator Converts binary supports into selection frequencies in [0, 1]; useful when base selectors return subsets instead of scores.

These aggregators directly implement the score-based pooling and selection-frequency strategies summarized in the Aggregation Methods section of the paper.

Rank-based aggregators

Defined in pyensemblefs.aggregators.rank, they operate on score matrices but internally convert them to ranks per bootstrap (1 = best) and then combine these ranks. They inherit from pyensemblefs.aggregators.base.RankAggregator, where lower values are better:

  • pyensemblefs.aggregators.rank.MeanRankAggregator Mean rank across bootstraps.

  • pyensemblefs.aggregators.rank.MedianRankAggregator Median rank across bootstraps.

  • pyensemblefs.aggregators.rank.ConsensusRankAggregator Conceptually equivalent to mean rank, kept for semantic clarity.

  • pyensemblefs.aggregators.rank.BordaFromRanksAggregator Borda fusion from rank input; if the input does not look like proper ranks, it is automatically converted from scores.

  • pyensemblefs.aggregators.rank.TrimmedMeanRankAggregator Alpha-trimmed mean of ranks, discarding extreme ranks before averaging.

  • pyensemblefs.aggregators.rank.WinsorizedMeanRankAggregator Winsorized mean of ranks, clipping extreme ranks to alpha-quantiles.

  • pyensemblefs.aggregators.rank.GeometricMeanRankAggregator Geometric mean of ranks, emphasizing consistently high positions.

  • pyensemblefs.aggregators.rank.RankProductAggregator Rank-product aggregation (log-domain), where lower values correspond to features consistently near the top.

These correspond to the rank-based consensus family discussed in the paper.

Subset-based (voting) aggregators

Defined in pyensemblefs.aggregators.subset, they assume that the bootstrap outputs are binary supports (0/1), and aggregate them using frequency and voting rules. They inherit from pyensemblefs.aggregators.base.BinaryAggregator and ultimately produce a binary mask of selected features:

  • pyensemblefs.aggregators.subset.MajorityVoteAggregator Uses selection frequencies and applies a majority threshold (e.g. 0.5); optionally enforces a maximum top_k by keeping the most frequent features.

  • pyensemblefs.aggregators.subset.TopKBinaryAggregator Selects exactly top_k features with highest selection frequency.

  • pyensemblefs.aggregators.subset.ThresholdAggregator Selects all features whose frequency is above a fixed threshold τ.

  • pyensemblefs.aggregators.subset.QuantileThresholdAggregator Selects features whose selection frequency is above a given quantile.

  • pyensemblefs.aggregators.subset.WeightedMajorityVoteAggregator Weighted voting over bootstrap supports; each bootstrap can have a different weight.

  • pyensemblefs.aggregators.subset.FDRControlledFrequencyAggregator Uses a binomial model and Benjamini–Hochberg FDR control to select features with statistically significant selection frequency.

  • pyensemblefs.aggregators.subset.ClopperPearsonCIThresholdAggregator Uses Clopper–Pearson confidence intervals on selection frequency to retain features whose lower CI bound exceeds a threshold.

These classes implement the subset-based voting and FDR/CI-based frequency rules described in the Aggregation Methods section of the paper.

Approval-based (ABC) voting aggregators

The module pyensemblefs.aggregators.abcvote connects ensemble feature selection with approval-based multi-winner voting via the abcvoting library.

In this setting:

  • Each bootstrap (or selector run) is interpreted as a voter.

  • Each feature is interpreted as a candidate.

  • A bootstrap’s selected features form that voter’s approval set.

  • An approval-based voting rule selects a committee of size top_k, interpreted as the consensus feature subset.

Core classes

  • pyensemblefs.aggregators.abcvote._ABCBase Internal base class for ABC voting aggregators. It:

    • Checks that input results is a binary matrix of shape (n_bootstraps, n_features).

    • Builds an abcvoting.preferences.Profile where each row’s approved features become the voter’s approval set.

    • Defines common scoring modes ("av", "sav", "slav") used by ABC-based aggregators.

  • pyensemblefs.aggregators.abcvote.ABCVotingRule Generic wrapper around a single abcvoting rule. It:

    • Receives a compute_func (e.g. compute_seqpav, compute_cc).

    • Chooses a safe algorithm using _pick_safe_algorithm(), avoiding Gurobi-based algorithms.

    • Computes a winning committee of size top_k.

    • Returns feature scores based on score_mode:

      • score_mode="av" → sum of approvals (Approval Voting-like).

      • score_mode="sav" → Satisfaction Approval Voting–style normalization: each voter distributes weight equally among approved features.

      • score_mode="slav" → same as "sav" (Shapley-like satisfaction).

    • Stores:

      • self._committee_ → set of selected feature indices.

      • self.selected_features_ → binary mask of the winning committee.

      • self.final_ranking_ → indices sorted by decreasing score.

  • pyensemblefs.aggregators.abcvote.ABCVoteAggregator High-level adapter that conforms to a simple interface:

    • Accepts boot_results as:

      • an iterable of subsets (feature indices or names), or

      • an iterable of 1D binary masks of length n_features.

    • Converts them into a binary matrix R using _to_binary_matrix.

    • If top_k is not provided, infers a reasonable committee size as the median number of approvals per bootstrap.

    • Builds an ABCVotingRule via make_abcvoter().

    • Returns a pandas.DataFrame with columns

      • "feature" – feature name

      • "score" – ABC-derived score (AV/SAV/SLAV-like)

      sorted in descending score order.

Available ABC rules in pyensemblefs

The catalogue of supported ABC rules is defined in pyensemblefs.aggregators.abcvote.SAFE_RULES. Each entry specifies:

  • rule_id – identifier understood by abcvoting.abcrules.Rule

  • func – the computing function from abcvoting.abcrules

  • score – scoring mode ("av", "sav", or "slav")

  • prefer – preferred algorithms (avoiding Gurobi)

The following rules are currently exposed:

  • Approval Voting family

    • "av" Uses abcvoting.abcrules.compute_av(), scoring with raw approval counts (score="av"). Equivalent to selecting features that maximize total approvals.

    • "sav" Uses abcvoting.abcrules.compute_sav(), scoring with satisfaction approval voting (score="sav"), where each voter splits unit weight among approved features.

    • "slav" Uses abcvoting.abcrules.compute_slav(), with score="slav". Internally uses the same scoring implementation as SAV in this wrapper.

  • Sequential proportional rules

    • "seqpav" abcvoting.abcrules.compute_seqpav(), sequential PAV-like rule with SAV-style scoring (score="sav").

    • "seqslav" abcvoting.abcrules.compute_seqslav(), sequential SLAV variant.

    • "seqphragmen" abcvoting.abcrules.compute_seqphragmen(), sequential Phragmén rule with score="sav".

    • "seqcc" abcvoting.abcrules.compute_seqcc(), sequential Chamberlin–Courant with SAV scoring (score="sav").

    • "revseqpav" abcvoting.abcrules.compute_revseqpav(), reverse sequential PAV.

  • Phragmén-type and resource-sharing rules

    • "phragmen_enestroem" abcvoting.abcrules.compute_phragmen_enestroem(), Phragmén–Eneström rule, scored via SAV (score="sav").

    • "equal_shares" abcvoting.abcrules.compute_equal_shares(), Equal Shares rule with fractional scoring (score="sav").

    • "minimaxphragmen" abcvoting.abcrules.compute_minimaxphragmen(), minimax Phragmén rule with SAV scoring.

  • Proportional and fairness-oriented rules

    • "rule_x" abcvoting.abcrules.compute_rule_x(), a proportional justified representation–oriented rule (SAV-based scoring).

    • "maximin_support" abcvoting.abcrules.compute_maximin_support(), maximin support rule focusing on fair representation with SAV scoring.

    • "eph" abcvoting.abcrules.compute_eph(), an egalitarian proportional heuristic with SAV scoring.

    • "rsd" abcvoting.abcrules.compute_rsd(), Random Serial Dictatorship-based rule with AV-style scoring (score="av").

  • Classical multi-winner rules

    • "pav" abcvoting.abcrules.compute_pav(), Proportional Approval Voting using SAV scoring (score="sav").

    • "cc" abcvoting.abcrules.compute_cc(), Chamberlin–Courant rule, again with SAV-style scoring.

    • "monroe" abcvoting.abcrules.compute_monroe(), Monroe’s rule with SAV scoring.

    • "greedy_monroe" abcvoting.abcrules.compute_greedy_monroe(), a greedy approximation of Monroe (SAV-based scoring).

    • "lexcc" abcvoting.abcrules.compute_lexcc(), lexicographic Chamberlin–Courant.

    • "lexminimaxav" abcvoting.abcrules.compute_lexminimaxav(), lexicographic minimax AV rule, with AV-style scoring (score="av").

  • Consensus-oriented rules

    • "consensus_rule" abcvoting.abcrules.compute_consensus_rule(), a consensus-based rule that works with AV-style scoring.

Using ABCVoteAggregator

A typical workflow is:

from pyensemblefs.aggregators.abcvote import ABCVoteAggregator

# boot_results: list of subsets (indices or names) or binary masks
boot_results = [
    {"f1", "f2", "f5"},
    {"f1", "f3"},
    {"f2", "f5", "f7"},
    # ...
]
feature_names = ["f1", "f2", "f3", "f4", "f5", "f6", "f7"]

agg = ABCVoteAggregator(rule="seqpav", top_k=10)
df = agg.aggregate(boot_results, feature_names=feature_names)

print(df.head())

This yields a pandas.DataFrame with features ranked by an approval-based voting rule, giving a consensus view of which features are most strongly supported across bootstraps and base selectors.
